articles.headline: 57% of consumers fall for greenwashing
articles.description: Most of us fall for greenwashing, and those of us who care about the environment are even more susceptible.
articles.introParagraph: The Environmental Defenders’ Office (EDO) recently called out two of Australia’s largest super funds for greenwashing, but they’re not the only offenders.

content.value: The Environmental Defenders’ Office (EDO) recently called out two of Australia’s largest super funds for greenwashing, but they’re not the only offenders.
The EDO sent letters to HESTA and UniSuper recently, raising serious concerns about greenwashing. For both funds a key issue is their investment in gas giant Santos.
The letters question whether UniSuper and HESTA have interrogated how an investment in Santos can be in line with the funds’ net zero by 2050 commitments.
“Santos is expanding its oil and gas production in a manner that is inconsistent with the climate goals of the Paris Agreement and a net zero emissions by 2050 pathway,” the EDO said.
Meanwhile, UniSuper and HESTA aren’t shy about making claims in their marketing about investing with the planet in mind.

On UniSuper’s homepage the fund states: “We're a responsible investor. We care about our environment and human rights and seek to ensure that the companies we invest in do too.” That statement appears next to a cartoon of people watering the planet with a watering can.
HESTA’s homepage under ‘Why choose HESTA?’ reads: “Climate action - From solar energy and wind farms to recycled water. We’ve established ourselves as an industry leader in climate action.”
Greenwashing works on most of us
Behavioural Insights Team associate adviser Saul Wodak recently completed research into how greenwashing impacts consumers.
Unfortunately, the study found greenwashing works. Over half, 57%, of consumers believed that greenwashed claims were a reliable source of information about a company’s eco-practices.

Consumers who self identified as being very concerned about climate change and environmental issues were more susceptible to greenwashing. Being educated and engaged with these issues isn’t protection alone from falling for greenwashing.
“I was surprised by that,” Wodak said.

“It’s hard to know exactly why greenwashing works but we think it might be because environmentally concerned individuals are looking for environmental cues in advertisements. They're just naturally more primed to look out for actions that companies might be doing to signal whether a company is a good or a bad environmental actor.”
Why isn’t greenwashing illegal?

Wodak explains that because greenwashing is in every sector - from supermarket aisles to financial institutions - consumers have become used to it. He suggests an independent third party star rating system, like those used on nutrition labels, might be able to help.
“With greenwashing, I believe legislation is still catching up,” he says.

Recently, a lawsuit was filed in New York against retail giant H&M accusing it of greenwashing its Conscious Collection products, which were advertised as requiring less water to manufacture when they may actually
use more water than other clothes
In the finance world, the Australian regulator ASIC has put out
new guidance on greenwashing
and claims it will be cracking down - though actions are yet to be seen. The US regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, is also requiring
better disclosures
of ESG matters.
In Europe, the Frankfurt offices of Deutsche Bank and its investment arm DWS were
raided by police over allegations of greenwashing
. And France has brought in laws so
greenwashing can be punished with fines
Layers of greenwashing in super

When it comes to financial products, it’s especially hard for consumers to make informed decisions. The super fund they choose will have many underlying assets it invests in - Santos is an example of one of those assets that many funds invest in.

“So often financial products that are labelled as being environmentally friendly might have investments in a certain proportion of fossil fuel companies or high polluting companies. They also might have a particular screening protocol, that according to them is ethical, but it might defy what the common consumer would think of as environmentally friendly in a common sense way,” Wodak says.

“I think there is often a real breakdown in what the average consumer or average layperson would consider to be ethical, or socially responsible, or environmentally friendly, and how funds use those labels.”

In the cases of UniSuper and HESTA, the company causing problems for them - Santos - has been accused of greenwashing itself. There’s currently a court case on foot, brought by the Australian Centre for Corporate Responsibility (ACCR), which accuses Santos of greenwashing in its “clean energy” claims.

ACCR has a number of concerns about Santos’ sustainability statements and marketing failing to be backed up by actions and evidence. One concern is that carbon capture and storage plays a significant role in Santos' plans to reach net zero, but the viability of the deployment of that technology is not clear.
Santos has also made big claims about the role of blue hydrogen (hydrogen produced from natural gas) in decarbonisation. The process of producing blue hydrogen involves the release of methane.
Methane has 80 times the warming impact of carbon dioxide
for the first 20 years after it is released and methane from the oil and gas supply chain accounts for 23% of emissions - for perspective, coal mining accounts for 12%. The gas industry has
downplayed the impact of methane
on global warming.

So the UniSuper and HESTA members that have engaged with the EDO to express concerns about greenwashing could be seen to be experiencing layers of greenwashing - from the gas industry, Santos, and their super funds (allegedly).
There is an upside though - Wodak’s research shows that when consumers are educated on greenwashing they are able to see through some of the common greenwashing tactics and make better decisions.

Wodak argues that through a combination of regulators getting tougher on egregious greenwashing, independent labelling to show how legitimate environmental claims really are and education on greenwashing tactics it is possible to reclaim green from the greenwashers.
How can you spot greenwashing?
Look out for
token gestures

. Statements like “our offices are carbon neutral” from an electricity company or “we plant a tree for every reusable bag sold” from a supermarket are examples of token gestures. While these gestures themselves are not harmful, they are used in marketing to distract from the parts of the business that are having bigger negative impacts on the environment.
Be wary of companies that
leave it all to you, the consumer

. A restaurant chain switching to paper straws or an airline asking you to pay to offset your flight, then using these consumer behaviours in marketing to bolster their green credentials is a greenwashing red flag.
A huge problem in financial services is
not being specific

. By using vague terms like “Socially Responsible Investment Option”, financial institutions can essentially define what “socially responsible” means. Some consumers will likely be surprised to find companies that have had recent high profile scandals like Rio Tinto in super funds’ socially responsible options.
Look for the evidence.

Companies should be able to show proof behind claims. For example, if you see a “net zero by 2050” claim without indications that there is a plan in place or an emissions reduction goal for 2030, that could be a red flag.
Take
carbon offset claims
with a grain of salt. Offsetting is going to play a part in achieving net zero for a lot of companies, but not all offsetting techniques are created equally.
Carbon capture and storage
, which a lot of fossil fuel companies are betting on to achieve net zero, is an unproven technology that scientists have criticised. The Australian carbon credits system is
currently under review
after a whistleblower revealed many credits for offsetting are a “sham”.

articles.headline: Ten investors responsible for 49% of emissions
articles.description: New research has revealed that almost half of the world’s emissions are held under the influence of just 10 investors.
articles.introParagraph: New research has revealed that almost half of the world’s emissions are held under the influence of just 10 investors.

content.value: The paper, published in the journal
Environmental Innovation and Societal Transitions
, mapped the ownership of the Carbon Underground 200.

The Carbon Underground 200 is a list of the top global publicly-owned coal, oil, and gas reserves owners ranked by the carbon emissions embedded in their reserves. These 200 companies hold 98% of global fossil fuel reserves in the form of oil, gas and coal.

“If these reserves are burned, it is estimated that it would generate an additional 674 gigatons of carbon emissions; 20 times greater than global carbon emissions in 2019 and three times greater than our global carbon budget,” the researchers said of the Carbon Underground 200.

“Based on updated estimates for our global carbon budget, we calculate that the combined 647 gigatonnes of potential emissions held by the CU200 nearly triples the 230 gigatonne carbon budget that remains in order to safely stay within 1.5◦ of warming. Consequently, the emissions potential of the CU200, examined in this study, is substantial.”

As all 200 companies are publicly listed, they are owned by a variety of investors from around the world. The researchers traced this ownership, using data from Bloomberg. They found that ownership is extremely concentrated, with the largest investors and sovereign wealth funds essentially holding enormous proportions of the world’s fossil fuel reserves in their portfolios.

Unsurprisingly, the two largest passive investors in the world - BlackRock and Vanguard - top the list, with another passive investment giant, State Street, in fourth place. Sovereign wealth funds from India and Saudi Arabia also make the top 10.
Collectively, these ten shareholders own 49.5% of the emissions potential from the Carbon Underground 200.

In order of the significance of their ownership, the researchers listed the top 10 investors as: BlackRock, Vanguard, the Government of India, State Street, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Dimensional Fund Advisors, Life insurance Corporation, Norges Bank, Fidelity Investments, and Capital Group.

Rounding out the top 20 were: Bank of New York Mellon, JPMorgan Chase & Co, Russian Federation,  Shaanxi Coal & Chemical,  Adani,  Citigroup, HDFC Asset Management, China Investment Corporation and Geode Capital Management.

BlackRock especially has been vocal in claiming it is moving away from fossil fuels, towards investing for a sustainable future. In January 2021, Blackrock committed to achieving net zero by 2050 or sooner.
Its appearance at the top of this list demonstrates how much influence on climate change one company could have, but also how distant its current investments are from its net zero rhetoric.
The researchers acknowledged that net zero commitments and pressure from those who put their money with firms like BlackRock does have the potential to have impact.

“Though traditionally ambivalent, capital markets now actively engage in innovation trajectories through their influence on resource mobilisation, in part due to an increased recognition and response to calls for sustainability,” they said.

However, researchers cautioned that these ownership revelations should also be seen as evidence that pressure from investors that care about climate change isn’t enough on its own, policy intervention on an international scale is likely still the answer to disincentivize these companies from burning the carbon reserves they own.

“While voluntary commitments are on the rise, policy interventions may still be required to transcend the path-dependent inertia of capital markets that stifle radical innovation,” the researchers said.

“The results not only assert that financial markets can influence the trajectory of sustainability transitions as enablers for socio-technical transitions, but also exemplify that power is concentrated among just a handful of powerful and path-dependent financiers. We reiterate that reduction of emissions exposure without reductions in production is simply not enough to mitigate the climate crisis.”

articles.headline: When is it okay to profit from war?
articles.description: As a result of the war in Ukraine, coal has enjoyed soaring prices. But what are the ethics involved in money and war?
articles.introParagraph: Recently investment platform Superhero sent an email to its offering some insights from investment professionals. The title of that email was "Why coal is still king".

content.value: Recently investment platform Superhero sent an email to its offering some insights from investment professionals. The title of that email was "Why coal is still king".
“For thousands of years, humans have been mining and burning coal as a form of energy and heat,” Superhero said.
The
"deep dive" into coal
continued: “In recent years however, environmental concerns and a green energy boom have battered coal’s public image.”
But, thanks to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine fortune is once again favouring “king” coal. Or so Superhero would have you believe.

Specifically, Superhero was spruiking Whitehaven Coal to its users - pointing out that the ASX’s third largest coal producer (behind BHP and Yan Coal) has benefited from the soaring price of Australian coal caused by the European energy crisis.
You can trade Whitehaven Coal on Superhero with just $5 brokerage, the platform informed readers.
Well down in the article, Superhero does acknowledge some of the downsides to coal.

“The issue with coal relates to its longer-term prospects. We know for example that countries including Australia are introducing zero-emission targets and that environmental and political pressures prevent us (rightly) from burning it indefinitely,” it said.

“Growing public pressure on banks and financiers and fears of being left with stranded assets meanwhile could make it increasingly difficult for coal miners to expand or find capital should they require it.”

Stranded assets are a serious risk for all fossil fuel companies. Research from the University of Massachusetts Amherst has estimated that stranded assets in the oil and gas sector alone are going to see
US $1.4 trillion
lost for companies in the next 15 years.
Not only are stranded assets an issue, we’re now seeing mining companies failing to get projects off the ground as the weak long-term outlook for coal crystalizes.
South32 had to scrap
plans to expand its Dendrobium coal mine
, beneath Sydney's drinking water catchment, recently.

Superhero was just offering this glowing Whitehaven review to those interested in trading on its platform, but it’s a way of thinking about investing that’s pretty mainstream - basically, why miss out on profits from coal now just because one day we might stop burning coal all together?
In this instance though, those profits are as a result of a war.
In the super sector, funds were pretty quick to put out
press releases
letting us know they'd
divested Russian assets
as soon as the war in Ukraine began. They seemed to understand then that members would expect them to take an ethical stance.
And most Australian super funds will tell you they exclude “controversial weapons”. They might have a different definition of controversial than you do though.
Late last year the
Australia Institute and Quit Nukes
released research finding that most major Australian superannuation funds have holdings in nuclear weapons companies, such as Airbus, Raytheon and Lockheed Martin.
At the time, AustralianSuper was found to have about $1.5 billion in nuclear weapons companies.

The report identified Future Super and Verve Super along with Active Super, Australian Ethical, Christian Super and Crescent Wealth as “leading the way” by divesting all companies with revenue from nuclear weapons.

It also found the super industry is out of step with community expectations on weapons. The vast majority (78%) of Australians want total transparency on whether their super is in nuclear weapons, yet through misleading definitions and fine print funds get away with keeping their investments murky.
Is the investment industry out of touch with Australians on coal too? Research shows roughly
80% of us are concerned about climate change
, it’s difficult to square that with the argument that coal is still king.

articles.headline: Should we “get it through our thick skulls” that oil and gas can be green?
articles.description: J.P. Morgan chief executive Jamie Dimon says increasing oil and gas production does not conflict with climate action goals.
articles.introParagraph: J.P. Morgan chief executive Jamie Dimon recently said increasing oil and gas production in the US does not conflict with long-term climate change action goals.

content.value: "We should focus on climate. The problem with that is because of high oil and gas prices, the world is turning back on their coal plants. It is dirtier,"
Yahoo
reported Dimon said in a client call.
"Why can't we get it through our thick skulls, that if you want to solve climate [change], it is not against climate [change] for America to boost more oil and gas?"
It’s not the first time Dimon has expressed these views.

“Oil and gas supply can be easily disrupted, either physically or by additional sanctions, significantly impacting energy prices. National security demands energy security for ourselves and for our allies overseas,” Dimon said in a letter to J.P. Morgan shareholders last year.

“Fortunately, we do not need to change our long-term objectives on climate change and greenhouse gases, and we should remind ourselves that using gas to diminish coal consumption is an actionable way to reduce CO2 emissions expeditiously.”
Future Super chief impact officer Emily Flood argues Dimon is plain wrong in his understanding of the emissions that cause climate change.
She points out that while Dimon refers to CO2 emissions, he’s conveniently directing attention away from the other greenhouse gas emissions that cause climate change.
Research from the
European Space Agency has used satellite data

to understand how methane emissions from oil and gas production compare to the emissions from coal, finding that methane leaks along the gas chain offset the climate benefits of switching from burning coal to natural gas.
Executive director of the UN Environment Programme
Inger Anderson has said
: “Cutting methane emissions is the best way to slow climate change over the next 25 years.”

That’s because methane has 80 times the warming impact of carbon dioxide for the first 20 years after it is released and because methane from the oil and gas supply chain accounts for 23% of emissions, while coal mining accounts for 12%.
Flood says Dimon’s claims that oil and gas production can be part of the climate change solution are a “classic greenwashing move.”

“Jamie Dimon is running a company that has over US $4.3 billion invested in coal and US $76.8 billion in oil and gas. He’s claimed that the US should boost investment into oil and gas and greenlight new projects,” she says.

“This is, of course, directly against the recommendations of expert bodies such as the International Energy Agency (IEA) and the recent IPCC reports, which all agree that absolutely no further expansion or new projects for coal, oil or gas should be approved.”

Flood added that the vast networks of researchers and scientists working for these agencies have developed multiple guidelines for achieving how investors, governments and industries need to adapt to the challenges posed by anthropogenic global warming - and still people like Dimon believe they know better.
“J.P. Morgan, the company itself, has a net zero commitment that discusses the need to transition away from fossil fuels,” Flood points out.
“But obviously, Jamie Dimon has no skin in the game whatsoever when he talks about the attractiveness of expanding fossil fuel activities in the US.”

J.P. Morgan is one of the largest fossil fuel financiers in the world. According to a recent report from climate change think tank InfluenceMap, J.P Morgan poured US $81 billion into fossil fuel projects in 2020-2021 alone.

InfluenceMap looked at 30 international banks which finance fossil fuel production, finding 29 of them - including J.P. Morgan - have set net zero by 2050 targets. The ongoing financing of fossil fuels by these institutions suggests others may share Dimon’s views that emissions reductions can coexist with fossil fuel production expansion.

For this reason, Flood adds that Dimon has a financial incentive to allay any fears J.P. Morgan investors might have that fossil fuel assets may become stranded assets, and result in losses, if governments intervene to act on climate change.

“He’s just a nice guy, who’s never heard of methane and just assumes that there will be buyers on the other side of the deal when he wants to walk away from fossil fuels once governments start to transition to renewable energy and demand drops off,” Flood says.
“He’s definitely got a plan. Nothing to see here.”

articles.headline: The weird, shady world of carbon credits
articles.description: The government has committed to reviewing Australia’s “sham” carbon credit system after a whistleblower revealed that up to 80% of Australian carbon credits are fraudulent.
articles.introParagraph: The government has committed to reviewing Australia’s “sham” carbon credit system after a whistleblower revealed that up to 80% of Australian carbon credits are fraudulent.

content.value: The Albanese government kicked off an independent review of Australia’s carbon credits system shortly after winning the election, in response to a whistleblower alleging up to 80% of carbon credits in Australia are a “sham”.

Andrew Macintosh is a professor at Australian National University and has worked in climate policy for more than 20 years. Among many other roles he chaired the Domestic Offsets and Integrity Committee, which oversees the method for the carbon trading scheme, for six and a half years. Macintosh has been a part of establishing the carbon trading system in Australia, is embedded in Australia’s climate policy world and is a believer in environmental markets.

He’s now turned whistleblower though. He is calling for the Clean Energy Regulator, which regulates Australian Carbon Credit Units to be broken up, citing serious conflicts of interest and a history of low-integrity management.
What are carbon credits?
Last year, the Wilmot Cattle Company - based in Ebor, on the Northern Tablelands of NSW - made a groundbreaking deal with Microsoft.

The beef producer had been focussed on its drought resilience in recent years, and had developed grazing management techniques that maintain the health of its land so it could keep its cattle grass-fed, and therefore sell its beef at a premium to grain-fed competitors.
The grazing management techniques were, according to the company, hugely successful - resulting in both well-fed cows and healthy farmland.
Then the cattle property’s healthy soil was turned into carbon credits, measured and marketed by a carbon credit start-up called Regen, and sold to Microsoft.
Microsoft could now point to cows grazing outside Armidale and say those cows, in those fields, were part of the company’s many-armed approach to combating climate change.
The move was lucrative for Wilmot too. So lucrative, that the company’s website barely mentions beef anymore.

A trip in The Way Back Machine shows that in 2019 the company still placed an emphasis on being environmentally responsible, but at that time its website largely promoted Wilmot's grass fed, antibiotic-free beef product.
Now, the website refers to grass fed “cattle” rather than beef and focuses firmly on the technology that has allowed it to capture carbon in its soil.
Wilmot is owned by Macdoch Investment Group - the family office investment vehicle of Alasdair MacLeod, Rupert Murdoch’s son-in-law and a former News Corporation executive.
Macdoch also invests in Impact Ag, which advised Wilmot on the Regen deal and Maia Grazing, the software which allegedly made Wilmot’s grazing techniques so good.
Beef farmers being part of the solution to climate change does seem odd, weren’t we all once told to enjoy meat-free Mondays to lower our carbon footprint?
Not long after Microsoft bought Wilmot's carbon credits, its founder Bill Gates made headlines for telling the
MIT Technology Review
that wealthy countries should give up eating beef entirely and switch to synthetic alternatives if they are serious about fighting climate change.
“I do think all rich countries should move to 100% synthetic beef. You can get used to the taste difference, and the claim is they’re going to make it taste even better over time,” Gates said.
He even suggested regulation could be used in wealthy countries to force people to stop eating meat, as part of the effort of nations to reduce their carbon emissions.
Down in the dirt

The carbon credits Wilmot sold to Microsoft aren’t part of Australia’s government-run carbon trading scheme, administered through the Clean Energy Regulator, but they are emblematic of the complicated world of carbon credits.

A group of researchers from The University of New England analysed the carbon credits Wilmot sold to Microsoft, they found the increases in soil carbon claimed under the scheme were “far too optimistic”.

The researchers, led by Aaron Simmons and Annette Cowie, found no evidence Regen had physically sampled Wilmot’s soil before awarding the company carbon credits. The equation Regen used, they argued, was less accurate than physical sampling and didn’t take gravel into account among other issues.
“We believe inaccurate methods have led to the carbon increase being overestimated. Thus, it appears excess carbon credits may have been awarded,” the researchers concluded.
Like the researchers who looked into Wilmot's deal with Microsoft, Macintosh is unimpressed with many of the methods being used to assess the amount of carbon being captured or offset.
Like the other researchers, Macintosh is sceptical about soil credits, like the kind Wilmot sold to Microsoft.

“Soil carbon is essentially a function of the amount of biomass, organic materia, that is pumped into the soil. And what do you think is the primary driver of the amount of biomass that goes into soil, in a climate like Australia? It's obvious, it’s rainfall.”

As he explains it, the level of biomass (and therefore trapped carbon) in the soil moves up and down depending on rainfall. Carbon credits could theoretically be sold based on increases in trapped carbon above that natural fluctuation which is attributable to management activities.
“That additional management impact is likely to be orders of magnitude smaller than the variability you get from rainfall,” he says.
Conflicts abound
Macintosh explains that the carbon credit trading system in Australia started out with the best of intentions.

“When the carbon farming initiative first started and when the Emissions Reduction Fund first started… there was a real commitment amongst almost everybody who was involved to create a scheme of high integrity,” he says.

“But this stuff is hard. It's complex. And it's easy to make mistakes because you're dealing with counterfactuals, because in order to come up with these methods, you've got to work out what would happen in the absence of providing the carbon credit.”
As it stands currently, Macintosh sees the carbon credit trading system as being in a mess.
“Our numbers suggest around 70% to 80% of credits are not legitimate,” Macintosh says.

He explains that because carbon credit trading is a highly politicised field, and due to staff turnover, mistakes piled one on top of another and there was no system to force acknowledge mistakes and create accountability. The degradation of the carbon trading scheme was a slow creep but it was also accelerated by political and commercial interests.

Over recent years, Macintosh observed upward pressure on carbon credit prices, driven by demand for credits from the largest carbon emitters. Once the price hit $55 per credit, Macintosh believes then energy minister Angus Taylor stepped in to encourage more credits to be released into the market, in order to help the big polluters by driving the price of credits down.
One of the levers to pull to flood the market with credits, he explains, was just to drop integrity and standards.
“As the coalition’s era dragged on I think it moved from reluctance to admit error to, what I suggest, is a deliberate lowering of the bar on integrity,” Macintosh says.
“That was because there weren’t that many credits coming out of the pipe and there was an obvious need for them and demand for them from industry - particularly among the large emitters.”
Offering an example of some of the illegitimate credits in the market, Macintosh points out that people are making money by selling carbon credits for planting trees but the trees already existed.

In the section of the carbon trading scheme known as the ‘human induced regeneration method’, landholders are incentivised to remove livestock from areas and allow native forest to regenerate. Macintosh estimates 97% of these projects are located in areas that have never been cleared. He calls it a “nonsense” that credits would be allocated to trees that already existed.
Core to these issues is the governance of the Clean Energy Regulator.

“It makes the rules, it staffs the committee responsible for ticking off the rules, it enforces the rules, it administers the scheme, it issues the credits and it buys credits on behalf of the government. You couldn’t possibly have a more conflicted entity,” Macintosh says.

“And as a consequence, now the regulator is incredibly close to industry… The regulator is marketing carbon service providers’ activities on its own website. Could you ever imagine APRA running marketing material for any super fund on its website? Or ASIC doing the same for any company on its website? It's extraordinary behaviour.”

In perhaps an illustration of this cosy relationship with industry, Wilmot owner/investor Alisdair MacLeod has said his team is working with the Clean Energy Regulator to help develop the regulated market for soil carbon credits in Australia after Wilmot’s successful deal with Microsoft.
Investment risk
Now, Labor has committed to reviewing the scheme - but it has an enormous task ahead of it in untangling the up to 80% of illegitimate credits from the few good, high quality carbon credit projects.

“We need the incoming government to take some strong steps to restore integrity. That's going to mean turning the tap off for a whole bunch of existing projects that have low integrity, which is going to cause a lot of upset,” Macintosh argues.

Unless the government is willing to cause that upset and ruffle some feathers by shutting down low integrity carbon credits, Macintosh says the problem could just drag on endlessly. He points out that some projects have 20 years to run on the crediting periods.
“Unless something is done about that, the stink is going to be around the scheme for a very long time.”

Since 2014, when Australia disposed of a carbon tax, we have relied on carbon credits to incentivise companies to reduce carbon emissions. Projects can earn one carbon credit for every tonne of carbon offset. Like in the Wilmot example, the offsetting largely happens by previously carbon-intensive industries improving techniques and technology to lessen their carbon footprint, and by using nature or technology based techniques to remove carbon from the atmosphere altogether.
In Australia, carbon credits are split between the government-run Emissions Reduction Fund and the spot market, both overseen by the Clean Energy Regulator.
Earlier this year, the price of carbon credits plummeted as the market became flooded with new credits.
According to Future Super impact analyst Navi Mangalvedhekar, this led to some of the country’s biggest polluters being able to, essentially, engage in government-backed greenwashing.
“Cheaper, accessible and likely fraudulent credits have encouraged fossil fuel companies to purchase carbon credits while expanding fossil fuel projects,” she explains.

“Instead of addressing transition and historic emissions, carbon credits are being employed by the federal government and corporations to extract and burn more fossil fuels while retaining course for net zero by 2050, however flawed the underlying logic.”

Macintosh supports Mangalvedhekar’s view that Australia’s carbon credit system currently presents material risks that likely make many carbon credit projects an inappropriate investment for super funds.

“If you’re a super fund investing in carbon credits right now, I would hold off unless you are investing in really high quality projects - ones that are essentially immune from the integrity issues that have been raised,” he says.

“Labor will soon initiate a review into the scheme. If they have good people who are competent, and supported by competent people, they will find what we know to be the case. When that happens, it could expose investors to adverse outcomes.”
For example, in the human induced regeneration space Macintosh says most of the projects at the moment are unlawfully stratified.

“So if a regulator came in and simply applied the law, it would wipe out most of that method, which is the backbone for most of the carbon players in space. So I would be very, very cautious as an investor putting money in anywhere near this unless I've done really thorough due diligence on the types of projects I'm investing in, and ensuring that you're not exposed to policy related risks and compliance related risks,” he warns.
While Macintosh is hopeful the system will improve, his whistleblowing has largely been met with denial.
The Clean Energy Regulator flatly denied Macintosh’s claims and said the human induced regeneration method has high integrity standards.
Wilmot also denied the claims of the University of New England researchers, responding that “carbon measurement methodologies are an evolving science”.

Meanwhile, demand for methods to offset carbon emissions has possibly never been higher as so many corporations and organisations have made net zero commitments recently. Those projects that are seen as already having credibility despite existing in the troubled system are proving especially popular.
